You like to have some degree of security and predictability. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

Given my risk-averse nature and preference for predictability, I would choose the strategy that offers more stability and less variability in earnings. In this game, choosing R provides a higher payoff (45$) when the opponent also chooses R, but there's a risk of earning nothing if the opponent picks B. On the other hand, choosing B always guarantees some return, albeit lower (12$).

However, since the game has 75 rounds, it's possible to optimize for the long-term outcome by considering the expected value of each choice. If I pick R, I expect to earn 45$ when the opponent picks R and 0$ otherwise, which results in an average of (45 * p + 0 * (1-p))/2, where p is the probability that the opponent also chooses R. Similarly, if I pick B, I expect to earn 12$ for certain, so my average earnings are just 12$.

To make a rational decision, I would compare these two expected values. If the probability of the opponent choosing R (p) is greater than 0.4, it's more advantageous to choose B, as the expected value of B (12$) is higher than the expected value of R. On the other hand, if the probability of the opponent choosing R (p) is less than or equal to 0.4, it's better to choose R.

Since I don't have any information about my opponent's strategy, I can only assume that they are rational and will also make a choice based on expected value calculations similar to mine. Given this assumption, both of us will likely choose the strategy with the higher expected value, which leads me to believe that p > 0.4 (otherwise, we would both pick R). Therefore, choosing B seems to be a safer and more rational choice in this game.
